review: Playing again after the announcement of the Great Circle. Last played The Emperor's Tomb when it came out in the original Xbox days. Very nostalgic and actually having a great time. I'm using keyboard and mouse as I couldn't get the bindings right on my Xbox Series-style controller. But it works quite well and the default bindings are pretty much spot on with what I like. Some of the turret sections (the planes level) are now super easy when I recall getting stuck on that part 20 years ago. But I am in this for the nostalgia not for the challenge so it's all-in-all a great time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036097842', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 626, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 626, 'last_played': 1708022297}
review:
A great game. Has 2 puzzles that are a bit annoying, near the end of the game, but it's not too bad once you get some practice on it. The game doesn't use checkpoints or manual saving, so if you die you are sent back to the start of the map. This makes dying an actual punishment in this game, as opposed to being able to save-scum. Ammo management is an important factor in gunfights, as in most scenarios hand-to-hand combat is more rewarding to conserve resources.
The music is somewhat repetitive, though I would assume audio files take up the most space... Since this is an older game, this can be overlooked as a technical limitation.

author: {'steamid': '76561199529452194', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1023, 'last_played': 1710699272}
review:
A very good Indy adventure.
You can have fun playing this game even if you are not an Indiana Jones fan.
In my opinion there is one small problem.
The watering holes where you can pour water into a bottle to heal yourself are far from each other during the more difficult moments of the game, but it doesn't interfere with the gameplay. The bosses are easy to defeat. I recommend the game. :) :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198864558567', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2, 'playtime_at_review': 420, 'last_played': 1712118657}
review: Alright serious review here, this has got to be the best Indiana Jones game I've had ever played in my life. Ever since seven years old Indy was my "superhero," I've watched all the movies, beat the whole Lego Indiana Jones 2 game, even had that shit on my Nintendo DS, and ever since I picked up this game it felt like a whole new world to seven year old me. The maps, the atmosphere, the weapons, the music, the enemy's, the characters, the bosses, the action, the adventure just everything about this game is remarkable and well worth playing even 20 years later, holy fuck im old

author: {'steamid': '76561198144749083', 'num_games_owned': 497, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 58, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1707483086}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198388107832', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1072, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1072, 'last_played': 1628279280}
review:
The epitome of an Indiana Jones game! From the extraordinary dialogue (voice acting too!), thrilling combat, perilous jumping/swinging, to the many varying sights of nature and level designing, this game truly is the Holy Grail of being Indiana Jones. 

I played this game on mouse and keyboard and was just fine; Potentially even better given that it's easier to aim with mouse. The game's mechanics are not too dated at all and everything functions just perfectly. Don't pass up this chance to put on your fedora and gain some adventuring mileage! Every Indiana Jones fan should experience this story at least in some way, even if you watch it online!

author: {'steamid': '76561198190012409', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 824, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 332, 'last_played': 1705889169}
review:
I like this old game a lot, but the inability to save the game makes me play areas from the start over and over until I get pissed and have to quit for a while and come back to it. It can be very frustrating at times. So I give it an 7.5 out of 10.
I like to play this game for a bit after watching the movies.
The music and cut scenes, few that they are, carry it.
It still stands up well over time. (in highest resolution available 1024x768)
The story is OK, but when it gets into the spiritual part later in the game I find it kinda' tough going.
The lack of a weapon wheel, common in most modern games, kinda' hurts game-play, but I just usually duck, dodge, and dive my way through punching most enemies out.
That seems to be Indy's most OP weapon, his hands.
It's fun smashing pick up items over NPCs heads.
There have been a couple places I resorted to watching a walk-through. But just a couple.
I pretty much hate in game puzzles, but find these very easy and tolerable.

review:
Indiana Jones and the Emperor's Tomb is a classic platforming and combat-oriented adventure game from 2003.  The controls and camera can get take some getting used to, but this is a really solid Indy game with some memorable locations and enemies.

We're back in 1935, so there are Nazis to bash as well as Asian underworld members well-versed in martial arts, so get ready for some hand-to-hand fights!  Also a fantastic sound track that's perfect for the action.  Definitely recommended!

review: I enjoyed this game. This is what an Indiana Jones game should be. The sense of adventure, the different locations, the items. The artifacts are fun to collect too. I would give it four out of five stars. The only thing preventing a perfect score would be the saving system. I wish it had manual saving with the automatic saving feature. Also some of the artifacts don't save (the Ottoman Seal in particular). Other than that, a wonderful game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026218489', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 202, 'playtime_forever': 632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1697988608}
review:
Just finished my play-through of this over on Youtube (link at the end of the review for anyone who wants to see a sample of gameplay before buying) and had great fun with it, so here are some thoughts!

Firstly, this is a 2003 game and I was pleased to see it got released on Steam; I remember playing this back in the day as a teenager and enjoying it for what it was. In essence, it's a 3D platformer with plenty of run-and-gun action and fisticuffs to get your teeth into along the way. To be fair and balanced, there's nothing groundbreaking or revolutionary about the gameplay here; Indiana Jones and the Emperor's Tomb didn't do anything new or innovative. But, to its credit, what it did do, it accomplished quite decently. Overall, it's a fairly solid and pleasing game.

The story sees our favourite bullwhip-cracking, globe-trotting archaeologist being drawn into an expedition to find an ancient Chinese artefact with great powers. As always, there are bad guys who want to get it first - the Nazis are also after said artefact, but there's also a Chinese triad on the hunt as well. Cue an adventure that sees Indy hopping from destination to destination as he attempts to keep the artefact out of villainous hands! It gets pretty wacky towards the end, with supernatural as well as human foes - but then again, wackiness is what you usually expect from Indiana Jones...

One of the first things I always loved about this game was the visuals; though it's an old game, they're still pretty to look at. On top of that, most of the game's levels and chapters are all fairly distinct from one another (visually speaking) - from the jungles of Ceylon to the dark, gothic spires of Prague, from the minarets of Istanbul to a Hong Kong opera house and more, I always found some of the levels to be quite pleasing to the eye.

Another element of the game I loved is the soundtrack. There's a great set of musical tracks in every level to accompany your adventures and get your heart thumping as you fend off baddies and explore strange and wondrous locations - including the game's adaptations of the classic Indy theme tune, which is always a good way to get your adrenaline going as you fight off hordes of bad guys with your trusty whip, revolver, bare fists or whatever other weapons are close to hand.

But one of the really solid and enjoyable aspects of this game, for me, is the combat - especially the melee combat. Sure, there are plenty of guns you can get your hands on, but the melee system is particularly fun. Clicking combinations of the left and right mouse buttons will have Indy use his fists to perform different moves; I'm not sure if this has any actual effect in combat other than to look cool, but hey - I like it, and the number of different moves suggests the devs put a lot of attention into it. On top of that, you can use your bullwhip - one of my favourite moves is to grab someone around the neck with it, pulling them towards you so Indy can deliver a strong left hook. Plus, in many levels there are objects in your environment that you can use in melee combat as well - such as chairs, glass bottles, shovels, machetes/bladed weapons, even the legs of broken tables. If ranged combat is more your forte, then the game has you covered there as well - besides Indy's revolver, many levels also provide plenty of other guns (though bear in mind that they don't have unlimited ammo).

Are there any issues with this Steam port of the game? Well, there were one or two minor things. With this being an older game, you may need to do some configuration to put it into a more modern resolution (the community guides will probably help with this). Though of course, putting the game into a larger resolution may have some unintended side-effects - you might see things that wouldn't have been visible in the original version of the game. For example, there was one cutscene where an enemy NPC walks off to the side of the camera - in the original version of the game he would just disappear from view, but because I'd configured the game to run in a higher resolution, it meant I could still see him as he appeared to noclip through a door. I imagine this normally wouldn't have been visible had I been playing in the game's original resolution. But this was an isolated instance, and no biggie.

There can also be the occasional minor glitch - again, it's an older game running on more modern systems, so there may be the odd thing that comes up. For instance, in one of the Hong Kong chase levels, there was a moment where one of the enemy vehicles came from the side and caused an instant-death. However, upon playing the level again, this glitch didn't reoccur - so it seemed very much a one-off thing.

All that said, Indiana Jones and the Emperor's Tomb is a great game from the early 2000s. If you enjoy action, adventure and 3D platforming, then I definitely recommend it!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xSUoPj3fSI8&list=PL05Yc3_TEBpPb8XWjX6WuQev44Ltr_PMj&index=1&t=1713s

author: {'steamid': '76561198019639843', 'num_games_owned': 511, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 971, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 971, 'last_played': 1568952124}
review: One of the best games ever, and i don't use that term lightly.  This is up there with MGS games in story and level design and just all the little things like the weapons and physics.  I could not stop playing this game when i was a kid, i spent hundreds of hours going through the campaign over and over and discovering new stuff every time.  Your heart will race during sections and then you'll find yourself exploring and finding your way to the next area, and having to do so by grabbing the explosives and using on x, so y crashed into the wall and then you go through that.  All the areas are fully fleshed out and have plenty to find and kill.  Combat is great, controls are fine, level design is top notch, if you didn't play this when your were a kid, i feel bad for you.

review:
Action and adventure. Interesting locations. Puzzles and challenges. Indiana Jones style and humor.
For Indiana Jones fans and other people as well.
While advancing in the game, the player must be ready to fight deadly enemies in entertaining combat. Using all available weapons and tactics is the key to beat thugs, Nazis, gangsters, agents and traps.

Game is a classic among action and adventure games. The story could have had more potential, but replay value is good anyway.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053063940', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 509, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 509, 'last_played': 1693278198}
review:
Play if you remember this from back in the day. Otherwise keep on scrolling. 

It's been nearly 20 years since I've played this game. It's rough around the edges, has some of THE corniest dialogue I've ever heard (and I've played Metal Wolf Chaos), and ultimately was overshadowed by much more polished games of the time. But it has a charm to it. A charm that only a C-list game you played to death when you were a kid could have. A game you play a lot but never really get around to beating. This marks the second time I've ever beaten the game and it very well may be the last. Feels good to relive a faded memory.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078554382', 'num_games_owned': 173, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1027, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 261, 'last_played': 1694396823}
review: I still remember being blown away by this game when it first came out. It was the closest I had ever felt to actually being inside an Indiana Jones film. It's not without it's issues (choppy framerate, dated controls, bad camera control) but those start to melt away for me as the music kicks in and I whip a pistol out of an enemy's hand. Definitely worth your time if you can pick it up for a few bucks. Hopefully someday it will get the remaster treatment it deserves.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038331677', 'num_games_owned': 200, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 540, 'last_played': 1708951085}
review: That giant gator scared me again, after 10 years.

author: {'steamid': '76561199126212282', 'num_games_owned': 192, 'num_reviews': 129, 'playtime_forever': 665, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 607, 'last_played': 1692532733}
review: The controls in this game are horrible. The game is incredibly hard, not because the puzzles or the combat was hard, but because the controls are soooo bad, Indy often does completely something different than you want him to do, the camera is horrible too, so often you can't even see where you're going, the traps are often unfair and kill you out of nowhere without prior warning. This game also loves wasting your time. It often kills you in some incredibly unfair way at some later point of the level and then makes you redo the entire level from the start, because there is no save system, no checkpoints or anything. One of the most frustrating games I have ever played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042012190', 'num_games_owned': 677, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 679, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 679, 'last_played': 1692144814}
review: Despite the aged design, the game crashing when I alt tab, infrequent checkpoints, the terrible controller support that required me to string together a steam input profile and the at times absurd narrative that sometimes left me a dribbling moron unable to comprehend anything about that chase scene with the cart... I fricking love this game. This is the kind of ps2 era AA jank that I adore. Just ambitious and polished enough to be cool but not forced to simply mimic whatever was popular at the time. This game is weird but fun, jank and yet somehow impressive and if it ever got a remaster I'd be all over it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025266541', 'num_games_owned': 3504, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 743, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 743, 'last_played': 1691599046}
review:
Although I think I prefer a smart puzzle-solving and platform-jumping Indy, and not a kinda derpy one-man-army Indy from this game, I am going to recommend Emperor's Tomb. It's a fantastic 6th gen era platformer/brawler with some pretty cool mechanics.

Story-wise it's the worst thing that I have ever encountered from this franchise (I think that speaks a lot after The Dial of Destiny) but it's still a fun adventure nonetheless that ties in with The Temple of Doom quite satisfyingly. Worth a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014631950', 'num_games_owned': 316, 'num_reviews': 125, 'playtime_forever': 804, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 804, 'last_played': 1689326073}
review:
[h1]Fortuna y gloria, ¬°all√° voy![/h1]

Este juego es [b]perfectamente jugable en Steam Deck sin toquetear nada[/b], ¬°hasta le instal√© un parche para pantalla panor√°mica y se ve espl√©ndido en 1920x800!

[b]Por favor Steam, cambia la valoraci√≥n a "Jugable".[/b]

Este juego es una deuda que ten√≠a pendiente hace cerca de 20 a√±os (¬°lo jugu√© de ni√±o en Xbox all√° en 2005 aproximadamente!) y por fin puedo decir que me lo pas√©.

En primer lugar sumarme a la queja de que no entiendo por qu√© Steam ofrece como idiomas el Franc√©s, Italiano y Alem√°n (aparte del ingl√©s, evidentemente) cuando este juego cuenta con un nada desde√±able doblaje espa√±ol. En fin, eso se arregla f√°cil buscando en el apartado Comunidad de este juego en Steam, sustituyes los archivos pertinentes y ya est√°.

Ahora s√≠, vamos Indiana Jones y La Tumba del Emperador, la precuela directa de Indiana Jones y El Templo Maldito. Una cosa que me ha sorprendido much√≠simo de este juego es lo bien ambientado que est√° en el mundo del rey de las aventuras del celuloide, pues bien podr√≠a ser una nueva pel√≠cula, y todo gracias a los personajes (han clavado la personalidad de Indy), los escenarios, los escenarios, la historia ¬°e incluso la m√∫sica! No est√° compuesta por el famoso John Williams, pero es muy muy fiel a sus composiciones. Gran trabajo por parte de Clint Bajakian.

Hay una gran variedad de enemigos. Habr√° de todo: espadachines turcos, cazadores de marfil... y s√≠, s√≠, tambi√©n hay nazis.
Usaremos armas para abrirnos paso ante estos enemigos, hasta MP40s. Puedes tambi√©n hacer uso de ciertos elementos arrojadizos que te encuentres en el nivel: mesas, sillas, botellas...
Hay mucha variedad en 15 horas de juego tambi√©n, tiroteos, plataformeo adictivo, jefes muy diferentes y distintas localizaciones. No te aburres.
Los controles son tosquillos, es inc√≥modo jugar y puede que acueste acostumbrarse. Morir√°s mucho en ciertos niveles, pero por lo general no es un juego demasiado dif√≠cil.

En cuanto a t√©rminos de rejugabilidad, puedes encontrar y recoger distintos artefactos

En fin, por lo general gran juego que ha aguantado el paso del tiempo a pesar de haberse estrenado en 2003, ¬°20 a√±os!, que se dice pronto. Y gr√°ficamente no se ve tan mal tampoco.

[b]8 / 10[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198047534142', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 794, 'last_played': 1692968087}
review: Zuletzt hatte ich das Spiel vor ca. 15 Jahren in seiner X-Box-Version auf der originalen X-Box sowie auf der X-Box 360 gespielt. Ich hatte die Steuerung per Gamepad als hakelig empfunden, speziell die Flucht vor von Becks Panzer via Peitschensprung hatte ich als sehr frustrierend in Erinnerung. F√ºr mich war die PC-Version von Steam daher eine angenehme √úberraschung: Sogar die Panzerflucht schaffte ich beim 2. Versuch, und insgesamt empfand ich die WASD-Steuerung als sehr viel angenehmer. Auch das Zielen per Maus, besonders mit dem Maschinengewehr auf der Seilbahn, fiel mir sehr viel leichter als noch vor 15 Jahren mit dem Gamepad. An Schicksal von Atlantis und Turm von Babel reicht die Kaisergruft meiner Meinung nach nicht heran, aber unterhaltsame Action bietet sie auf jeden Fall. Folgendes f√§llt mir bis heute √ºbel auf. Die Geschichte ist zwar durch filmreife Zwischensequenzen gut und spannend erz√§hlt. Aber w√§hrend Atlantis und Turm zu Babel auch eine interessante Hintergrundgeschichte zu erz√§hlen wissen, in der Geschichte und Wirkungsweise sowohl von Orichalcum als auch babylonischer Artefakte glaubhaft erkl√§rt und motiviert sind, bleibt die Kaisergruft immer wieder in zum Teil sehr beliebig wirkenden Versatzst√ºcken h√§ngen, die niemals erkl√§rt werden und selbst mit allen zugedr√ºckten H√ºhneraugen schlichtweg keinen Sinn ergeben. Wie zum Teufel kommen Huangdis Spiegelfragmente nach Prag, nach Istanbul, nach Indochina? Wer platzierte es in den R√ºcken eines Frankensteinmonsters? Wer hat das Frankensteinmonster erschaffen und warum, und was hat Huangdis Spiegelfragment √ºberhaupt damit zu tun? Welche Wirkung hat es? Einen einzigen Tagebucheintrag, ein Audiolog - alles h√§tte man uns anbieten k√∂nnen, um diese abstrusen Plotholes, von denen es hier einige gibt, plausibel zu machen. So aber bleibt als Makel der Eindruck blo√üer Beliebigkeit und auch Faulheit an der Story haften, und da helfen die kinoreifen Zwischensequenzen wenig.  Spa√ü hatte ich trotzdem, nach 13.2 Stunden war's durchgespielt. Das reicht dann vielleicht auch.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051730896', 'num_games_owned': 531, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1670, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1604, 'last_played': 1709326361}
review:
Favorite game of my childhood. Still holds up pretty well. Really nice level design and setpieces, as well as a great original story that expands Indy's journeys. Get the game and be amazed by a passionate game that is truly underrated. Especially for 1,74‚Ç¨ in the ongoing summer sale right now, the game is undeniably an actual steal.
I personally don't mind the outdated graphics at all, the gameplay definetly makes up for it in my opinion - probably even without an nostalgic point of view.

On the technical side though I would recommend looking for mods/config edits concerning resolution and framerate. 

For my fellow German players, I'd also suggest patching the game to be uncut to make the game feel like an acutal Indy movie with some genuine  ùîëùîûùî∑ùî¶-ass kicking.
(Link to guide: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2453720458)

review: A fun adventure that really embodies the fun of Indiana Jones. It's incredible how after 20 years later, this game is more fun than a lot of Triple A titles. It's a little wonky in its control schemes and clunky 00s gameplay mechanics, but the game design, music, atmosphere tone, and puzzles are really enjoyable. I'm only on Level 2 rn, but I can't wait to complete this and feel like I was on a satisfied and original adventure with the good doctor.

review: I played this game when I was young on our old family computer. It was so hard back then, I don't think I got passed Istanbul on easy mode. Right after the announcement for Indiana Jones 5, I started getting back into everything Indy, including this game. So happy I chose to revisit this title. It's a little dated, and the mechanics are a little clunky, but man is it still fun to play. Easily the best Indiana Jones game ever made. Looking forward to the new Bethesda title!

author: {'steamid': '76561198065782397', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 95, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1687819452}
review:
Soo after getting myself Indiana Jones and the infernal machine, I also got me Indiana Jones and the Emperor's Tomb. So far I really like it. It has a newer control-scheme, which allows you to use the mouse like in newer games like Tomb Raider to look around and attack enemies. The graphics are kinda dated, but not as old as in Infernal machine. Resolution won't support 1920x1080 or higher though. 

Pros: 
- nice fistfights against goons, 
- good controls, 
- nice environements (eventhough I merely know the temple yet, but have seen screenshots from other nice levels), 
- nice graphics, 

Cons (Possible SPOILER): 
- crocodiles - especially the giant one at the end of the first chapter. Why does it always have to be bloodthirsty sharks or bloodthirsty giant crocodiles in those underwater-levels 
 - the swimming-controls (maybe it works better with a controler?)

author: {'steamid': '76561199025059268', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 604, 'last_played': 1687428042}
review: Quiz√° no est√© al nivel del m√≠tico Indiana Jones y el Destino de la Atl√°ntida en cuanto a argumento (despu√©s de todo, son dos juegos muy diferentes), pero tiene la parte de acci√≥n que le faltaba a aquella: este juego es puro Indiana Jones. Respeta la esencia del personaje y sientes que de verdad est√°s viviendo una de sus pel√≠culas. El dise√±o de niveles es excelente, la m√∫sica es bestial y la jugabilidad muy adictiva. Es un juego que ha envejecido bien.

author: {'steamid': '76561199261253036', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 3526, 'last_played': 1711414115}
review: This game is awesome. The controls are a step up from Infernal Machine and feel good to use (expect for jumping and swimming). The plot is pretty interesting, and it fits the Indiana Jones universe, and I hope Disney doesn't retcon it simply just because it's a game. The boss fights are pretty good, but the first one with the giant crocodile has unfair mechanics at times. The voice acting is good, but is a bit stereotypical at times. The game spelled Qin Shi Huangdi's name wrong, though, it spelled it like Ch'in Shih Huang Ti. The first three levels (Ceylon, Prague & Istanbul) are quite long, but the rest feel like they're just the right length. The final boss has a great idea, but it's too fast and I speedran it and got 0:54.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048783034', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 782, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 782, 'last_played': 1682519430}

author: {'steamid': '76561198161483791', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1020, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1020, 'last_played': 1682106723}
review:
Grew up with the movies, so I decided to give the game a try. I would recommend it, however there is some mechanics in the game that might not have aged to well, the graphics are what you would expect for 2003, but the gameplay is smooth.  
Pros
- Engaging combat, satisfying melee, guns are kinda average with the exception of the revolver. 
- Smart enemies that when disarmed will grab nearby furniture.
- Challenging but cool puzzles.
- Harrison Ford voices Indy.
- Even if you have not played the game, it feels nostalgic, from the music alone.
Cons
- Swimming can be real janky.
- Trashy but so bad it's good Lucas Arts dialogue (this can also be a pro).
- Story is fun, but pretty cliche.
- Does not support wide screen (there is a patch, but it's not vanilla).
- No checkpoints in any level, which can get really frustrating. Patience is a virtue in this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198023087366', 'num_games_owned': 1237, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1059, 'last_played': 1682104341}
review:
Play with Indiana Jones and the Infernal Machine instead. That one also has clunky controls but the gameplay is very good. This game on the other hand has way too much fight scenes, with hard enemies on later stages, the fighting controls are mostly OK but sometimes buggy. The overall controls are much worse than the old Tomb Raider games and you can't save the game so when you die because of the bad hitboxes (like a moving wall kills you when it shouldn't) you need to start over again. I learned most of the later maps because I played them through like 10 times, it's not fun.
The story is nothing special, the ending is very short. It could have been a good game but because of the controls and the lack of manual saves it was enraging about 50% the game time. I finished it just to be able to say that it's done.

author: {'steamid': '76561198319216066', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 257, 'last_played': 1680947633}
review:
I owned this game as a kid, and I couldn't help but buy it again when it caught my eye. Much to my dismay, it was not simply youth and inexperience that kept me from getting very far as a child. To be blunt, this game is bad. Nostalgia is the only thing that saves it from being utter garbage for me. I felt enough of a connection to my inner child to have a decent enough time, but this game is *rough*. 

Let's count the ways:

-The camera is hectic and never seems to want to let you take a good look around without bringing Indy with you, except for the first person POV mode, which is nice but also would (and should) be pointless if the camera just behaved better. It's not too terribly bad, but it never felt quite right. The whole experience comes off sluggish and janky as a result.  

-The enemies are tanks. I played on normal difficulty and these guys took more abuse than Invincible before going down. I'm talking enough whip attacks to make a dominatrix faint and more stab wounds than you'd see in a Southeast London bar brawl at 3 AM. Frankly, your fists are your best weapons, except for the revolver (which is the only decent way to deal with most foes); apparently Indy is 1/10th Kyrptonian, because he punches with the power of a goddam bazooka. I guess it's thematic? Indy does melee a lot in the movies, but they didn't have to make the whip a wet noddle because of that. 

-Swimming is a crime against humanity. The control scheme for the rest of the game is decent enough, but swimming is uniquely frustrating. Crocodiles are far and away the most terrifying enemies in the game, not because of what they are, but because half the time Indy is break-dancing at the bottom of a river or lake and they just so happen to run into him and decide to take a bite. 

-The graphics are...about what you'd expect for mid 2000s. Not the worst part of the game, but temper expectations. 

-Voice acting is much the same. None of it is too awful, and the Indy voice is better than many I've heard, but the handful of voice lines get repeated every 2 minutes. You might as well just turn the sound off outside cutscenes. The sound design is somehow more frustrating, especially for animals, and especially for rats. After 2 minutes of being near rats in the 2nd level I was ready to wander the streets of LA to find a hobo to murder. They're not bad sound effects, but they go off CONSTANTLY. I am not joking, there was ZERO down time between a lot of these. 

All of this combines with a fairly un-interesting story to make a game that was probably acceptable in its day, but at this point, stay away. The only reason I even bothered to boot this up was I remembered fondly playing as a kid, and I should've left it in my memories. Unless you're a bad video game connoisseur or an Indy fanatic, stay away.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025217807', 'num_games_owned': 8, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 144, 'last_played': 1628236391}
review:
If adventure has a name... it must be Indiana Jones and the Emperor's Tomb

Ever since Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom fans have been wanting more adventures in the exotic orient of China. This game doesn't disappoint on any level. It is the most immersive Indiana Jones game to date using innovative effects like spatial audio that can only be experienced by playing while wearing headphones. Its technical detail and experience hold up strong 20 years later. My only complaint is that this Steam release has lost the native Mac OSX support that the game had in the 2000's.

author: {'steamid': '76561199184789295', 'num_games_owned': 114, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 1018, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 898, 'last_played': 1708627509}
review:
I wish I found out about this game earlier. indiana jones is modelled after harrison ford himself yet the game offers an all new original story which isn‚Äôt inspired by the movies. for a 2003 game. indiana jones offers great gameplay. the use of the iconic whip, the variety of melee weapons, the use of firearm. for a 20 year old game, it holds up well graphically and is easily accessible on modern resolutions. the game worked like a charm at 60 frames on 1440p for me. great level designs and locations, each level takes you into a different location where something new‚Äôs usually introduced . the iconic whip works like a grappling hook and as a weapon which allows you to disarm enemies. a great action adventure game with fairly tough combat, great platforming and intriguing puzzles. the only criticism I do have about this game is the lack of save points. the game automatically saves at given points through out the game which is usually the case for older titles. dropping into this game felt like a breath of fresh air. the game‚Äôs essentially like tomb raider and uncharted without the steroids. players who love uncharted and tomb raider will feel right at home while playing this game. for people who appreciate order games, I wholeheartedly recommend this game. 

the emperor's tomb leaves me intrigued for what machine games has in store for their upcoming indiana jones game. side-note, the game's just $2 dollars on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046323743', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 510, 'last_played': 1678472380}
review: Although the game is nowhere near previous Indy games in terms of story, puzzle and atmosphere, "The Emperors Tomb" fits quite well into the series¬¥ universe. Set in 1935 between the first and second feature films, Indy battles his nemesis, the Nazis, who have teamed up with a powerful chinese megalomaniac and his criminal network in Southeast Asia to recover an ancient, powerful artifact. Some sections play almost like a movie, and other levels are unfortunately quite unimaginative and surprisingly sloppy, even for a game from 2003. Apart from soldiers, thugs and ivory hunters as well as resurrected chinese warriors, there are hardly any varied enemy types in the game, some passages therefore seem relatively lifeless. But what really stands out and makes this game unique is the fact that you can play through the game without firing a single shot - thanks to the fistfight system! Compared to "The Infernal Machine" and "Fate of Atlantis", the game is quite short and does not offer much replay value. There is, however, the possibility to collect some well-hidden artifacts, which unlock a small art gallery - but that¬¥s it. Unfortunately, far too often an incredible amount of potential was wasted in this game, for no good reason. One can only speculate what a masterpiece the game could have been if more time and passion had gone into it. But the nostalgia hits pretty hard and as an Indy fan I had (and still have) fun playing this game once in a while.

author: {'steamid': '76561198219280476', 'num_games_owned': 154, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 98, 'last_played': 1707723418}

review:
A freaking good game.
Puzzles are variable and fun. Same for combat. Story is fine, music is legend. The game has the spirit of Indiana Jones's movies.
No manually saving, wrong move can lead to death and thus losing progress. I actually like it, make the adventure feels more excited.
With some tweaks, you can play in HD with 60 or more fps. Graphic still looks very good for a 20 years old game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198999226054', 'num_games_owned': 193, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 586, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1674105128}
review:
So, I am an Indiana Jones fan. I love love love the movies, and I've always wanted a game like it. Unfortunately, I did not want to play this game because of how... primitive it looked. Suppose that's why I'm a fan of Uncharted because it's like Indiana Jones but... voiced by Deadpool. But this review ain't about Uncharted, it's about the Emperor's tomb. 

So, as an Indiana Jones fan, I can appreciate how the game takes on several elements pretty well. This is a game coming off from 2003, the same year... Star Wars knights of the old republic came out, so I think it's pretty good. I mean, i can't say much about the graphics, comparing it to the games now, but I can't say that, because 1. like I said, this is a 2003 game, and 2. I was born in 2004 and only played this game on steam only now. But judging by the games of that era, I'm gonna say the graphics are pretty good for that time. The story is easy to follow, and like an Indiana Jones story. But I mean, like I said, it's like a story, There's something off, I don't know what it is, which make it Indiana Jones. Maybe more whip puzzles. The gameplay is freaking awesome. The game coming from 2003 and it's quite smooth, me playing as Indiana Jones whipping from place to place. However, I feel the combat system is a bit... finicky. Use your left mouse button and right mouse button for attacks. See, I'm going to the first Uncharted as a reference. in Uncharted: Drake's fortune, there's two combat moves you can do: all square or square triangle square. But even with the "Diversity" of combos you can do, at least they have a point, like one of the combos will give you more ammo after the enemy dies. With Indiana Jones, you give many combos, but two things hinder me. 1. if two people gang up on you, you're gonna have a bad time, and 2. if you have a gun, aiming system is lesser than crap. When you zoom in with a gun, you go into first person and look around to shoot, except it's technically not looking around, because I tried head-shotting a guy below me, and it missed despite the site being on him. Like, what is it, Resident Evil 4 pre-remake? Artifacts, granted are a good idea, and it's not that many, unlike Uncharted. (Having PTSD on trying to 100% the game). Guns are quite nice to use although not exactly versatile. I love the detail that Indy can lose his hat. Controls are generally smooth, but camera angles sometimes get janky, messing up jumps which could cost you your life. I also love the tension and heartaches the game gives during some areas, like (Spoiler alert) [spoiler] a giant croc coming up at your ass [/spoiler] or some booby traps. 

Overall, this game in my opinion gets a 6.5/10. Can't wait for another Indiana Jones game, Bethesda.

Oh, crap. Not Bethesda. Just kidding, I actually think they might put up a banger job.

I would say maybe look up some reviews for specifics but for the price and the fact it runs with no problems, gonna be a big yes from me dawg.

author: {'steamid': '76561198195401935', 'num_games_owned': 1082, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 997, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 995, 'last_played': 1688469258}
review:
One of the best games to ever exist. A timeless classic that feels fresh no matter when you play it with a great story and great AI.
   The only complains I have is the error when you alt tab that idk if every1 has and the lack of achievements. If this game would have any achievements i'd love to list it in my completionist section along with 3 other games. Because of that I took my own liberty to make some achievements in case one of the Steam publishers decides by some miracle to see this.

   -disarm an enemy using your whip - Lost something? (A picture of the whip) 
   -finish the game - Happy ever after (A picture of the mirror of dreams) 
   -finish the game on the hard difficulty - The end (A picture of the dragon from the hard difficulty setting)
   -hidden achievement: find all 30 artifacts and unlock the gallery - The completionist (A photo of one of the masks, prefferably the jade one)
   -complete the first chapter without using skulls - Improvised bait (A picture of a skull with the general prohibition sign over it)
   -pick up your hat 10 times over the course of the game - I wouldn't be myself without it (A picture of Indy's hat)

author: {'steamid': '76561198080371220', 'num_games_owned': 137, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 584, 'last_played': 1612200998}
review:
A timeless masterpiece with a great sense of adventure (just like the movies). 
While the visuals themselves did not age too well, the game has a nice attention to detail. A wounded Indiana Jones will behave differently, jumping a lot makes Indiana Jones breathe heavy etc.

The meele combat system is surprisingly deep and satisfying. You can also collect hidden relics and artifacts which are not related to the main story, that's a lot of fun as well. All of that really adds towards the mystery and mood of the original movies!

author: {'steamid': '76561198051241973', 'num_games_owned': 664, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 586, 'last_played': 1687601238}
review:
One of my favourite action adventure games of all time. I've completed it at least 4 times. It's a great Indy game, has all Indy gimmicks. The combat system is perhaps its strongest suit, you can pick up some random object like a table leg, shovel, a bottle etc., you can take your opponent's weapon away with your whip, chain attack using left and right punches (LMB and RMB), there are dozens different combos. You visit many interesting locations, you use the whip to swing and punch Nazis. Also, you collect some hidden artifacts. And the game serves as an awesome prequel to The Temple of Doom!
There are, however, a few things that aren't so good. Some locations are poorly designed, repetitive, somehow hollow and don't really make that much sense when you think about it (the castle in Prague). 2D textures around the world break the immersion. It's also short and that challenging.
I highly recommend it to Indiana Jones fans! To the others... maybe not so much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035900635', 'num_games_owned': 301, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 1167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1167, 'last_played': 1670182185}
review:
Reviewed on Steam Deck

I‚Äôd never played this ( or any of the Indiana Jones games, tbh) before so I had no nostalgia going in.
I played The Emperor‚Äôs Tomb on Valve‚Äôs venerable Steam Deck. I had a few issues and so changed the compatibility layer to Proton Experimental. I should also note that I had to map the ‚ÄòEnter‚Äô and ‚ÄòEsc‚Äô keys (confirm and back buttons respectively) in order to navigate the in-game menu and enable the games‚Äô built-in controller support. Even then there is a visual glitch that regularly appears, that of a line bisecting the screen at random intervals. Other than that the game runs pretty well although you can‚Äôt get proper fullscreen or widescreen aspect ratios. There is some jank, but many games of that period featured janky controls or lack of polish. Even the menu features jank, or bad design. To load a game you press Enter, then load game. Then you select your save file then back you go to the main menu to press start again. Why? A pointless step. None of this jank is game breaking though. These days the game feels like a low budget indy (no pun intended) or AA game but back then I imagine the graphics were pretty good and the voice acting and music are very authentic to the movies. There‚Äôs no quick save, instead the levels are broken up into stages that have to be completed before the game will auto save. This can be highly frustrating as I‚Äôm sure you can imagine and by far the worst part of the game. You do get a lot of game for your money, however. The game is very large but sadly with a relatively small amount of story to sustain its length. The highlight was the Prague level with its gothic castle. I thoroughly enjoyed it. And then disaster struck. I decided to play the last level on my PC. I wanted to see how it looked on a large OLED TV. I load the game, noticing that the cloud save was up-to-date. Strangely only the first 3 levels were available on my save. I went back to my Deck. Now only the first 3 levels are available there as well. I‚Äôm absolutely furious!

0/10

review: A childhood favourite of mine which is still good fun to play. The plot is very true to an Indiana Jones movie, so much so that I have found myself now wanting to watch the films. The soundtrack is directly that of Indiana Jones and where new pieces have been composed for the game they fit in very well. The graphics are arguably dated but I don't have a problem with it because the game still holds up in terms of game mechanics and world-building, as well as the other factors described previously. In conclusion, a great game for a true Indiana Jones fan.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104178080', 'num_games_owned': 159, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 127, 'last_played': 1706735813}
review:
I will start by saying that I may be very biased in my review due to the fact that I grew up playing this game on my PS2. I have some really fond memories of wasting a weekend trying to get through the Prague levels for the first time. I can still remember the soundtrack almost beat for beat. I couldn't get enough of the atmosphere either, it truly feels like another Indiana Jones movie.

However, even though I have a lot of bias towards this game, it still stands as a fantastic game. The graphics are pretty impressive for when it came out. The soundtrack is extremely atmospheric. The level design is fantastic. Combat feels punchy, no pun intended. In fact, combat is fun, combos are satisfying to pull off and getting in fistfights with Nazis is always a great time. The story is fairly interesting though I got a bit bored in the later levels. The details this game has great, I especially like how Indy's hat can get knocked off. 

Overall, this game is fun. It's clear the developers had a lot of love for Indiana Jones and wanted to make a game honoring the films. If you are a fan of Indiana Jones, I would highly recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198859512016', 'num_games_owned': 59, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1008, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 215, 'last_played': 1710959977}
review:
Hello! I am Spy Gaming! I would like to give this game my honest review so i will describe the bad parts and the good parts, first let's talk about the playable character..

Indiana Jones is the main character, and the only playable character (without mods.) 

Let's talk about the movement of the main character. The movement is sometimes annoying, but it's okay. 7.5/10 My only complaint is that the underwater camera is annoying.

Now about the sound effects/voice, the sound effects are good, the voices are on point ngl. 9/10

Now about the story, The story is 8/10.

Now the combat system, the combat system is honestly good for it's time, since this game came out in the early 2000's. 10/10

Now, the checkpoints...Those's are somewhat annoying, since if you die on the last part of the level, you will start from the begginning which is...annoying... 5/10

Now, to give my rating about this game.

7,9/10, I recommend playing this game, since it's very nostalgic.

(i've also beaten this game 5+ times in the past)

author: {'steamid': '76561198818366614', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5991, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 592, 'last_played': 1683377158}
review:
This is a great game.

It is satisfying to punch the bajezuz out of these Nazis and gangsters. The levels, while low in graphical detail, are a fun challenge to explore. The game doesn't give you much guns or ammunition forcing you to get up close, which I liked since every enemy would be a breeze if every crate had MP-40 ammo.

The only problems I had were when you needed to do a chain whip swing, it was difficult to approximate how far forward I should have been before letting go and reclicking the whip button, resulting in numerous deaths. It was also disheartening whenever I died in a big section and had to start at the beginning of the section.

To summarize my thoughts, if a video game company wanted to do a remake of this game, I would wish the same amount of care that was put into the Mafia 1 Definitive Addition would be put into this.

Thank you

author: {'steamid': '76561199000013763', 'num_games_owned': 151, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 926, 'last_played': 1701313596}
review:
This game is very pro-shark and very anti-human. 
In all seriousness this game has a lot to it. Fifteen hours through I have seen about half a dozen completely different yet equally unique and memorable stages/levels, perhaps about 25-50% of the story, and I'm still being introduced to new mechanics, weapons and characters. The Emperor's Tomb has plenty of things going for it. But there are a couple of things you absolutely should know before you buy it and play it. Otherwise you might get understandably frustrated by early 2000's adventure game design.

First off is the save system. This game's save feature works whenever you go through a door to the next section/level. Thankfully this means you'll never forget a save, but this has the maddening flipside that you are completely at the mercy of whatever the level designers thought made a good stopping point. You cannot log off safely unless you have just entered a new section, because you WILL lose all progress from the last save point. Even worse, every death sends you back to the last save point, so a hard group of enemies towards the end of the level can only be re-fought after you redo the entire level. And levels can get long. Fortunately, I have found that after you have explored a level for the first time the knowledge of items, enemies, and puzzles within it speeds up any post-death reruns considerably, perhaps even a quarter of your original time. Unfortunately, this also means like every death forces you to speed run each section again when one of the best aspects about the game is working your way through the deliberately crafted levels. This save feature will definitely bring frustration, but I don't think it will stop your overall enjoyment of the game. Perhaps the best remedy of this is taking it in small sections, or calling it quits for the night if you die after a long session.

The next things I can think about are minor, but together they do play a role. The camera would definitely be considered "janky" today, this game has a limited number of old resolutions without mods, and Indy sometimes goes the opposite of where you think he is, all of which may combine and lead to unintended deaths. 

With all of that being said, this game is well worth your $6, if slightly stubborn in giving you it, if you know what I mean. As it is so old you may have trouble finding tutorials but I have done fine enough when I have gotten completely stuck. If that happens to you and you can't find a tutorial I suggest you watch a playthrough on YouTube of your level. 
7/10, would recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014146141', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 387, 'playtime_forever': 734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 430, 'last_played': 1662954679}
review:
Play through review 2022
Level of fail: 2K's Quality of Life
+Music
+Combat
+Voice cast
+Difficulty
+Story
+Some funny moments
+Cutscenes in general
+Characters you meet
+Puzzles
+Some cool cutscenes
+/- Can be fun when all the other issues aren't making you go full nuclear
-Shills promoting a broken mess of a game
-Auto saves are also a POS. Game will only save after you complete an entire stage of a mission. So if you die you start off from the last stage start. Extremely stupid and very, very annoying. Also a waste of time.
+/- Level design is interesting. Not a fan though.
-Camera is a POS and will get you killed. Likes to spin pretty fast in certain angles. Mostly when jumping or turning corners. Mostly when you need to do fast actions. Like swinging across something.
-Hit detection
-Lack of community patching
-Buggy mouse and keyboard controls
-Rope swinging can also be pretty buggy
-Chain swinging
-Very, very buggy when climbing or trying too. End up dropping down to your death. Companies want our money and respect and yet leave a game half-a.ssed and mostly broken. GFY.
-Lack of patch support
-Controls are a POS and will also get you killed

review: This is probably the best translation of Indiana Jones from movie screen to video game. The sound effects sound like they are pulled directly from the film, the Harrison Ford sound-alike does a stellar voice acting job, and the puzzles are suitable for the title. The outdated camera prevents it from becoming a perfect game, but overall fans of the franchise should check this one out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032007222', 'num_games_owned': 117, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1034, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1024, 'last_played': 1658056429}
review:
An honest attempt at making an action game about Indiana Jones.

Generally speaking it's not outstanding but it's still pretty fun!
There's a variety of weapons but I enjoyed barehanded melee the most due to how hilarious some combos end up being (and unless it's a large group of enemies, using guns is an Easy Win button, especially in normal mode).
You can vault, climb, even swim and use your whip to swing across gaps.
The game is kinda jank (which ironically enough added to the experience to me, seeing the AI doing weird things or not detecting you well sometimes), the cutscenes feels a bit undercooked at times but they still mostly do the job.
I have a soft spot for these lower profile action games (another one i loved is The Mummy for the first PlayStation).
It's janky, unpolished at times, but also exciting and engaging, and I definitely enjoyed my time with it!


So for short, if you are into old action games and also Indiana Jones, get this game (it's incredibly cheap too!)

Indy sucht mal wieder einmal einen Schatz aus China, Mythen zufolge ist es Verflucht und bringt Untoten Geister zur√ºck auf diesen Planeten. Die Deutschen & Chinesen sind ebenfalls auf der Suche nach diesen Schatz.

Parkour, Seil  zu anderen Seite zu schwingen  oder schneller als die Zeit Aktionen kommen noch oben drauf! Nat√ºrlich gibt es Bugs oder leicht Technischen Problemen aber f√ºr ein 2003 Spiel ist die Grafik heute noch anzuschauen!

Si te gusta Tomb Raider o Uncharted, este juego es para ti.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054004608', 'num_games_owned': 3276, 'num_reviews': 277, 'playtime_forever': 568, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 568, 'last_played': 1653848223}
review:
Indiana Jones and the Emperor's Tomb, what a game. From the music, setting, characters, story, locations and iconic Indy, this game has it all. The game features a great plot with twists that you'd expect from any Indiana Jones title. The iconic weapons like the whip and the revolver is also present in the game and it just makes you live the experience as you either swing, jump, grapple, shimmy, swim or shoot your way through a series of different locations all for a piece of an ancient Chinese artifact called the Heart of the Dragon. As you would expect, this artifact is not just an ornament, but rather a very active and cursed object.

Highly recommend this game. I've played this back when I still lived with my parents and playing on the PlayStation 2, and boy, were those the days. Amazing game. What awaits you at the end of your adventure?

Fortune and glory, kid...fortune and glory.

author: {'steamid': '76561198816414354', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 704, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 704, 'last_played': 1651545502}
review:
Una maravilla con mucha nostalgia, Lo jugue cuando tenia 11 a√±os y por culpa de este juego aprendi a guardar las partidas en la memory card, Ahora con 18 a√±os me sigue pareciendo tan bueno como el primer dia, el precio lo vale son 6 horas de juego seguidas que tienen de por medio mecanicas, esenarios, y acertijos que mas alla que se juegue en normal se te dificulta y mas de un golpe al teclado le vas a dar. Sin embargo hay partes que es dificil encontrar las pistas o ver como avanzar y te vas a tener que guiar por un tutorial como a la antiguita. 
Dejando eso de lado me parece muy buen juego, disfrute cada segundo y es como si estuviera en mi living tomando la chocolata mientra mi vieja hace pan casero un domingo en pleno oto√±o de 2010. ‚ò∫

author: {'steamid': '76561198856302457', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1449, 'last_played': 1651023694}
review:
Had this game on the PS2 back in '04, stumbled upon it here, and it is still a good game. 
The controls can be a bit jarring, so would recommend setting up a controller if you are motion sensitive as the camera is controlled by the mouse and can leave you quite disoriented at times. 

Overall still a fun story with some interesting ideas, would love a remake/remaster of this as it is, easily, the most playable Indy game!

Tiene su dificultad sin ser muy excesiva pero mediante vas pasando niveles, va aumentando.
Los gr√°ficos para ser un juego antiguo se ven bastante bien.

Tambi√©n es importante recalcar que no es necesario conocer las pel√≠culas de Indiana Jones para jugarlo ya que es una historia exclusiva.
Por tanto, si eres fan de los juegos de aventura y exploraci√≥n te gustar√°. Tiene rollo a lo Tomb Raider (algo normal siendo juegos similares) pero es mucho m√°s light. Probadlo y me decis :)

review: This game improves upon the previous title, Indiana Jones and the Infernal Machine, with much better visuals, smoothness of controls, and combat. author: {'steamid': '76561198116049208', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 308, 'last_played': 1702384012}
review:
[h1]There will never be a better video game[/h1]

If you've played it and you aren't convinced it's the best game that will ever be made, maybe you are forgetting it was this good in 2003. 

The perfect game is not about the best graphics - though this had top graphics in 2003, it's not about the best animations - though this had some of the best animations in 2003, it's not about the best sounds - though this has some of the best sounds up to date (music, sound effects, Indy's voice), it's not about the best story - though this has a proper Indiana Jones story involving Nazis, [b]It is about how the combination of all these traits and the atmosphere make you feel as a gamer while playing, and that's where Emperor's Tomb will remain unbeatable.[/b]

Simply put, you feel like Indiana Jones from the first 3 films. Having played this from the age of 3 I am biased I know, but I've played far 'better' games like Uncharted 4 which I will put down in the league of best in the world among The Witcher 3, but neither ignite a flame inside like Emperor's Tomb does.

If you play this and your heart isn't captured by the atmosphere, maybe you're too young and / or you are part of the problem with modern gaming, that with the exception of titles like Uncharted 4 has steered far and away from level-design focused development and into eye-candy and dopamine simulators. The leap from Uncharted 3 to Uncharted 4 is nowhere near the level of the leap between Infernal Machine and Emperor's Tomb.

author: {'steamid': '76561198892018770', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1683305912}
review: E' stato il mio primo gioco su pc di tanti anni fa. Rigiocarlo oggi dopo tanto tempo mi trasmette emozioni impagabili, sembra di essere tornato a quei tempi. Il gioco si commenta da solo: appena inizi vieni tuffato nell'avventura di Indy. Combattimenti, sparatorie, arrampicate e soprattutto tanta adrenalina condito da una colonna sonora meravigliosa. Unica pecca le meccaniche un po' invecchiate e il supporto al controller non sempre preciso. In conclusione: se sei amante del genere √® un gioco che va assolutamente giocato. Ci servono altri giochi cos√¨! Voto 10

review:
Esse jogo traz √† hist√≥ria da aventura mencionada no in√≠cio do segundo filme, O Templo da Perdi√ß√£o, onde o Indy tem caracter√≠sticas mercen√°rias em vender objetos raros para o mercado negro - uma atitude bem diferente da vista no final do primeiro filme, Os Ca√ßadores da Arca Perdida - ele vende os restos do primeiro imperador chin√™s para Lao Che, ligando √† hist√≥ria do jogo com o filme. √â percept√≠vel seu pensamento ambicioso em suas frases quando se coleta os artefatos.

Emperor's Tomb tem a ess√™ncia de um bom Indiana Jones. Ou seja, aventura, explora√ß√£o, elemento de arqueologia, combate corpo a corpo e artefatos (colecion√°veis). Cada luta voc√™ sente como se estivesse no filme Indy. Embora goste do The Fate of Atlantis e The Last Crusade o The Emperor's Tomb √© o melhor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198291540834', 'num_games_owned': 60, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1643990353}
review:
Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade is the third film in the Indiana Jones series. Released in 1989, it was directed by Steven Spielberg. Although it was the third motion picture released, the movie is chapter twenty-five in The Complete Adventures of Indiana Jones.

Set two years after the events of Raiders of the Lost Ark, the story follows archaeologist Indiana Jones as he discovers his estranged father has gone missing while seeking out clues leading to the Holy Grail. Guided in his search by his father's diary, Jones learns that the Nazis are also interested in the Biblical cup, and must overcome them to be reunited with his parent.

The movie was re-released on VHS in 1999, and twice on DVD in 2003 and 2008 respectively. The 2003 DVD was part of The Adventures of Indiana Jones box set containing the first three Indiana Jones films, while the 2008 release was promoted as a Special Edition of the film, as part of Indiana Jones ‚Äì The Adventure Collection (the original trilogy), then individually and as part of the four-film Indiana Jones - The Complete Adventure Collection.[1] The film received a high-definition home video release in 2012 as part of Indiana Jones: The Complete Adventures.

- zu viele nervige Gegner (nervig wegen unpr√§ziser Steuerung und st√§ndigem Munitionsmangel)

author: {'steamid': '76561199060286709', 'num_games_owned': 355, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 972, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 969, 'last_played': 1686693989}
review: Indiana jones is modelled after harrison ford himself yet the game offers an all new original story which isn‚Äôt inspired by the movies. for a 2003 game. indiana jones offers great gameplay. the use of the iconic whip, the variety of melee weapons. the use of firearm. for a 20 year old game, it holds up well graphically and is easily accessible on modern resolutions. the game worked like a charm at 60 frames on 1440p for me. great level designs and locations, each level takes you into a different location where something new‚Äôs usually introduced . the iconic whip works like a grappling hook and as a weapon which allows you to disarm enemies. a great action adventure game with fairly tough combat, great platforming and intriguing puzzles. the only criticism I do have about this game is the lack of save points. the game automatically saves at a given points through out the games which is usually the case for older titles. dropping into this game felt like a breath of fresh air. the game‚Äôs essentially like tomb raider and uncharted without the steroids. players who love uncharted and tomb raider will feel right at home while playing this game. for people who appreciate order games, I wholeheartedly recommend this game.

review: I've played this game at least once a month every year since I bought it in 2003. While simple, the fluid combat, adventure aspect and Indy theme just work for me. Regardless of how many good modern games keep coming out I always find myself drawn back to this one. Much like how many people feel about Resident Evil 4, this game has a formula that just works. I simply cannot recommend this game enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021174884', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 5229, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3128, 'last_played': 1696050766}
review:
This is one of the best adventure games I have ever played, and I am not just saying that for the Indiana Jones Franchise, but for any PC game in general. I would say this game is of the same genre as the Prince of Persia series, except that Prince of Persia is based on ancient times and does not involve guns, firefights or aircraft.

There is a lot of action in this game involving fistfights, firefights, etc. There is more fistfight than shooting and that just makes the game all the more interesting, in my opinion. Plus you need to get very good at making Indy jump, use his whip, and do both at the same time. There are several puzzles to solve and you need to take Indy to some locations on your own. There is no real map guiding you. You need to use your head for this, or you will not get anywhere. It is precisely in this respect that this game's experience is a lot like that of the Prince of Persia series. That is exactly what I love about it. 

You also cannot save whenever you want, which makes this game incredibly challenging. There are four parts in the game that are extremely difficult. You need to use your brain, and you need to muster up all the patience in the world to complete those four levels. You need to stay calm and composed to get through it. Try getting excited and you get Indy killed. Those stages I am talking about can be completed. You need patience and master Indy's movements. Once you get through these levels a few times, it becomes child play, even if you play again after several years.

The game is great. Certainly something worth the money. You do not need to be an Indiana Jones fan or know what he is all about to be able to play the game. Hell, I have only watched one Indiana Jones movie, but played three Indiana Jones games. You can understand what is going on quite easily. This game deserves all the five stars it gets and it gets that from me. 

I want to add Lucas Arts just did a phenomenal job with this game, and they were quick to release bug fixes. Contrast this to Ubisoft - I am yet to see bug patches for Prince of Persia: The Forgotten Sands. Sad that Lucas Arts got purchased by Disney.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116992041', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2167, 'last_played': 1637807365}
review:
Indiana Jones and the Emperor's Tomb is a worthy successor to LucasArts classics, like Fate of Atlantis. IJET has great gameplay, allowing Indy to run, jump, climb, shoot, hack, slash and brawl like he does in the movies. The fighting system allows the player more freedom of movement than I'd expected in a game as old as this one. Some of the opponents' fancy moves took me off guard, such as Shaolin Zombies doing a handstand, as they threw Indy head over heels, using their feet! Spirit-animated statues kicking at Indy after he'd severed their other body parts looked a bit Monty Python, 'it's only a flesh wound!' King Arthur and his knights and Dr. Jones both sought the Holy Grail, of course. 

Special mention must go to the liberal use of Indy's trademark whip, to swing across chasms and fend off attackers, although I couldn't get it to disarm villains, as the player is apparently meant to be able to do? It's a small gripe and perhaps I just couldn't figure it out. It's also tricky to keep Indy orientated in the right direction to face his opponents, at times but I got there.

The story is a typical Indy tale, where we firstly find our hero coming to the end of his previous adventure, leading into the main plot, when Indy meets Von Beck, a nasty Nazi in the same vein as those in the movies. Given that Marshall Kai, whom Indy meets a little later, is already a strong Chinese villain and the game has enough Far Eastern mythology around the titular Emperor, himself, it felt a bit repetitive to include the Nazis again. However, this allows for more challenges along the way, including the maddeningly hard tank chase in the penultimate level. This challenge took me the most attempts to beat out of the whole game and it's debatable whether it was worthy of inclusion, especially since the payoff is similar to the climax of a similar scene in Last Crusade. Still, it was a deeply satisfying climax, given the time I'd put into getting there. I even had to consult a walkthrough, which felt like cheating but, of course, I still had to actually defeat Von Beck myself.

I understand that a game like this has to have bosses of advancing difficulty throughout but some of them here rival Kingdom of the Crystal Skull's fridge-nuking scene in terms of suspending disbelief within Indy's world. The monstrous yellow-eyed crocodile near the start was a stretch, the steampunk Nazi automaton at the end of the Prague level was bizarre, edging on ridiculous and seemed to hint at further plot machinations that never occurred but the Kraken in the Istanbul level was absurd. I can't imagine such a monster being in any of the movies, which tend to avoid mythical creatures and focus on human villains, even if they use supernatural means. A monster like that would've possibly been too hard to create for the 1980's movies, as well as stretching credibility but it would still look like too much in the next Indy adventure, even with the capabilities of current CGI; look what happened when 'aliens' appeared in Crystal Skull! A creature like the Kraken belongs in Pirates of the Caribbean, not Indiana Jones. My bitterness over how long it took me to defeat that briny bastard might be affecting my view, here, however.  

It's funny how having Indy simply fill up his water canteen at an appropriately-placed fountain and taking a few gulps restores his health. Does Indy's receptacle possess the same healing power of the Holy Grail, or maybe all the water in this game is blessed? 

The voice acting was generally pretty good and David Esch does a passable Harrison Ford impersonation. I'm not sure why characters have to breath so heavily when they move, though. It seemed like Indy got out of puff from simply stepping over a stone and when characters fought, their physical exertions sounded positively rude! It sounds like they're sexy-fighting!

There are many moments inspired by the movies and the stepping stones challenge Indy faces within Last Crusade's Grail Temple seems to have inspired quite a few challenges later in IJET, where Indy has to tread on particular stones to avoid certain death. There's also the aforementioned 'tank' chase and taking on Nazi fighter planes, although it's just a shame the player doesn't get to pilot one, as in Last Crusade but I was still happy to shoot them down, like Henry Jones Sr. does. I also liked the skeletal spirits of the Emperor's victims looking and sounding like the floating angels of death from the end of Raiders. The involvement of Wu Han, a friend of Indy's whom we see at the start of Temple of Doom, which Emperor's Tomb leads into, is also a nice connection. Aptly, both titles sound somewhat similar.

Indiana Jones and the Emperor's Tomb still holds up after 18 years and it gave me a good Indy fix, before the release of the next movie!

author: {'steamid': '76561198085737350', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 682, 'last_played': 1627490147}
review:
I recently played this game to completion almost two decades since I first played it.  As per usual, when I play it ever five or so years, I thoroughly enjoy it.  I just wish it would be remastered.....especially since the new game is coming out soon.

Pros:
*Levels broken into small chunks
*Long game play when compared to modern games (even with knowing the puzzles, it took me 11 hours to complete; it took me six to complete Fallen Order)
*Game has aged well
*Great story line - I wish this game or Infernal Machine were used for the new movie
*It's only about five bucks on Steam
*Whats great is that this is a prequel to Temple of Doom

Cons:
*No quick save - I swear this used to exist in the game
*Controls could be updated.  The mouse scroll wasn't fast, making items/weapons hard to equip
*Fate of Atlantis and Infernal machine preceded this game.  Both had one of my favorite characters - Sophia Hapgood.  I wish she was included, but understand why seeing as this ties into the movies.
*Swimming will make you rage quit

review: For the low price this game becomes on summer sale of only 2 dollars it is an amazingly fun game, I think this is a must have for Indiana Jones fans who want a video game to play, the hand to hand combat is very fun, the gunplay is a tad bit mediocre but it's Indiana Jones like c'mon the movies aren't really known for big shootouts though they do have them, it is a little dated by modern game standards but I would still take this anyday over something like Tomb Raider and Uncharted, it has this great charm to it that is very spot on to the films, and for the price this is absolutely worth buying and playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091494295', 'num_games_owned': 865, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 960, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 960, 'last_played': 1624597835}
review:
Indiana Jones and the Emperor's Tomb has a lot of frustrating moments, from some shockingly difficult levels to cheap and annoying enemies to the sometimes clunky controls, especially when swimming. However, there's quite a bit to enjoy, to the point where it's a net positive for the game.

For a game that one expects to be set in China, there's quite a lot of variety in places to explore around the world, which gives a lot of neat setpieces for Indy to jump, whip, and fight across. The movement and combat, while alternating between fluid and clunky, is varied and fun for the most part, with vast improvements compared to the Infernal Machine. There is a lot more variety in different weapons and objects to use in the fights, enemies to encounter, and moves to traverse the locations. It's not entirely perfect: some enemies can stunlock you into cheap deaths, and the controls don't always make Indy go where you want him too, but I eventually got used to it and found the movement and combat to be pretty fun, minus a few frustrating moments.

The story is pretty decent as well, serving as a sort of prequel to Temple of Doom, though the timeline of characters meeting and their interactions aren't entirely consistent.  Additionally, In stark contrast to other Indiana Jones LucasArts games, there is shockingly little puzzle-solving beyond avoiding traps and platforming. It's much more linear than the other games, though that's not necessarily a bad thing.

While the game is prone to crashing sometimes and may need some modding to get the right resolutions, the Emperor's Tomb is a great action-adventure game that is highly recommended for anyone, Indiana Jones fan or not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198193863549', 'num_games_owned': 73, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 1555, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 63, 'playtime_at_review': 984, 'last_played': 1711510838}
review:
I love Indiana Jones. I love the movies, and if I had to guess how many times I've seen EACH movie, it be around 30 times in my lifetime. This game is a good meh sorta game and feels good compared to the movies, not as good, but good. 

Cons: Camera man can go fuck himself, controls can follow but maybe not as harshly, AI cannot decide whether it wants to beat my ass or not. A statue is harder to fight than a Nazi with an automatic machine gun.

Pros: The story is great, and if you get into it is really fun to see Indy and another one of his adventures. They're very good. The controls are annoying as hell but when you get used to them it is a breeze.

Also Kingdom of the Crystal Skull was a good movie IDGAF

Also Staff of Kings available for PC plz

author: {'steamid': '76561197968751857', 'num_games_owned': 114, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 812, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 812, 'last_played': 1618260738}
review:
Legende der Kaisergruft ist ein schwaches Indiana Jones-Spiel. Bereits im ersten Level offenbart sich der actionorientierte Grundansatz und das schwammige Konsolen-Gameplay in seiner kargen √Ñsthetik. Erst sp√§ter im Spielverlauf wei√ü das Spiel in puncto Atmosph√§re zu √ºberzeugen.

Schie√üereien und Schl√§gereien sind ohne Zweifel ein wichtiger Bestandteil in jedem Indiana Jones-Film. Der f√ºr das Franchise und insbesondere die Spiele typische Adventure-Part kommt in diesem Teil aber deutlich zu kurz. √úber weite Strecken wirft einem das Spiel stumpf Gegnermassen entgegen, die entweder im Nahkampf im Stile eines m√§√üigen Fighting Games oder im Fernkampf mit unbefriedigendem Gunplay beseitigt werden m√ºssen. Die qu√§lend langgezogenen Railshooter-Passagen sind der Tiefpunkt dieser uninspirierten Gameplay-Ausrichtung. Ein Gro√üteil der vermeintlichen R√§tsel dagegen beschr√§nkt sich auf ein simples Schalterbet√§tigen oder Bombenlegen. Richtige R√§tsel sind leider rar ges√§t.

Zudem ist der Spielverlauf sehr linear, wodurch sich kein wirkliches Gef√ºhl des Entdeckens einstellt. Dabei bieten die Story und die Schaupl√§tze durchaus Potenzial, so dass vereinzelt im sp√§teren Verlauf - u. a. durch einige Filmreferenzen - tats√§chlich ein Indy-Feeling aufkommt. Dass in der englischen Fassung der Protagonist aber leider nicht einmal von Harrison Ford gesprochen wird, ist dem Ganzen wiederum eher abtr√§glich.

Wirklich st√∂rend sind aber die altbekannten Konsolenport-Macken. So gibt es viel zu sp√§rlich gesetzte Autosave-Punkte, die immer wieder zu Frustmomenten f√ºhren, eine umst√§ndliche Handhabung des Inventars und ein unverl√§ssliches Autoaim. Die Steuerung per Controller auf dem PC gelingt, mal abgesehen von der widerspenstigen Kamera, sonst recht gut.

Genre-Fans werden m√∂glicherweise trotzdem ihren Spa√ü haben. Insbesondere wenn sie in dem Action-Fokus kein Problem sehen. Meiner Meinung nach trifft das Spiel den Kern der Indiana Jones-Marke damit aber nicht gut. Hinzu kommt der allgegenw√§rtige Konsolen-Muff. Die Referenz im Bereich der 3D-Action-Adventures √ºber Indy bleibt deshalb f√ºr mich das vier Jahre √§ltere Turm von Babel.
